fields.summary: euctl errors out when authentication.ldap_integration_configuration is invalid JSON

comments.body:
That error usually happens when you supply euctl with invalid JSON.  Do you happen to have a copy of the configuration that you can sanitize and attach to this bug?

\-\-debug output would also be useful, as it is for most other potential client-side bugs.

Yeah, so the example you posted privately is invalid JSON, specifically because of the trailing commas at the end of its maps.  Python is far less forgiving of those mistakes than Java.  Does euctl let you update that setting with the same value, but without the trailing commas?

EUCA-11604 also comes to mind as a way of working around this.

Customer reports that the property edit fails, which doesn't entirely surprise me:

{code}
run this command: euctl --edit authentication.ldap_integration_configuration
euctl: error: Expecting property name: line 17 column 3 (char 1363)
{code}

(He seems to have mashed up my request to him, and the response he got back.)

I've asked him to update the property using euca-modify-property. Will update once those results are in.
Customer successfully updated authentication.ldap_integration_configuration via euca-modify-property, and now reports that running euctl (with no args) works without issue.

Commit {{b674d5c}} adds fallbacks that make it do a few things with values that are not well-formed:

# {{euctl}} will silently ignore the problem since it does not display structures
# {{euctl --dump}} will output a warning and display the raw value
# {{euctl --edit}} will start one off a warning and an editor with the raw value.  It will not accept a new value until the error is corrected.

{noformat}
% euctl --dump cloud.network.network_configuration
warning: existing value of cloud.network.network_configuration is malformed; outputting it as raw text
...
{noformat}
